transcript.text: There are high costs for not complying with competition laws.

contentText.text: As the recent example shows, competition law violations can carry severe penalties. We need to avoid even the appearance of wrongdoing.

instructionText.text: Select each heading to learn more.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

tabText.text: Over the past five years, the U.S. government has exacted roughly USD$6 billion and the EU Commission roughly USD$8 billion in fines and penalties for antitrust violations.
Similarly, authorities in Asia (especially Korea, China and Japan) are becoming more and more active.
Competition law violations can have very serious consequences for our company's financial condition, reputation and continued success.
As well as fines imposed on the company, Johnson Controls could be sued for damages. These penalties are significant.

Employees who infringe competition laws can be fined and may even go to jail. For example:
  • Romano Pisciotti, an Italian citizen, was extradited to the U.S. and tried for bid rigging, price fixing and market allocation in the sale of marine hoses. He pled guilty, paid a USD$50,000 fine, and was sentenced to 24 months in prison.
  • The CEO of Canadian Environmental Services was sentenced to 63 months in prison after a conviction for bid rigging and fraud. He was ordered to pay a USD$12,500 fine and USD$3.8 million in restitution.
